Americans make decisions about presidential candidates based on things like debates and campaign speeches.
But that's not the only way the candidates create an image for themselves.
There are also the logos that adorn billboards, T-shirts and bumper stickers.
To find out more about what a logo can tell you about the person behind it, we go now to Michael Evamy.
He is author of the new book, ""Logo.
Welcome to the program, Mr. Evamy.
Hello.
How are you?
Fine.
Thank you.
Now, can you tell us, first of all, what should someone keep in mind if they're designing a logo for a person as opposed to let's say a company?
I guess one of the main high profile parallels would be in music or in the performing arts, where bands and musical performers have logos devised for them by professional designers.
It's quite an unusual brief for designers to try and encapsulate the personality or the political values in a single campaign logo.
And we have quite a mix amongst the presidential candidates currently running.
We've asked you to take a look at some of these logos.
And let's start...
Yes.
...off with the one for Barack Obama.
And can you describe a little bit about what it looks like and what it says to you about the candidate?
Yeah, of course.

It consists of a pictorial element on the left hand side of the logo, which is a circle with what looks to be a sun rising over a set of three red stripes which are curved to form a kind of agricultural or homeland type landscape.
And the message is very much one of optimism of a new start, of new horizons.
It probably encapsulates or anticipates how voters might like to view the future.
In other words, it identifies with its audience.
And I don't think any of the others really do that very successfully.
This is the one, for me, that is most successful in design terms.
Let's take a look now at some of the other logos.
On the Republican side, there is Rudy Giuliani, and his logo was simply his first name, it's in white characters on a blue background.
What does that say to you?
Well, it's very interesting, that one.
Every one knows who he is just by having the name.
It's a kind of shorthand for himself.
Everyone knows what it means.
Every one knows that he is running for president.
Why have anything more?
It's kind of look great on placards.
It's not, in design terms, a real looker.
But it's probably going to be very effective.
Turning to Hillary Clinton's logo, underneath her name is a flag and it looks a little bit like a campaign streamer.
And there was a cartoon recently here in the New York Times and it said it looked as if she's already celebrating victory.
Is there any way that voters kind of pick up on those subliminal messages?
Possibly.
I think what's puzzling about that is the three stars.
I'm not an expert on American - the American presidential system or politics, but I kind of wonder what the three stars signify.
There are two key rules on any kind of high profile logo design, and that is to keep it simple and to make sure that it works on bumper stickers or placards or badges.
It's got to make - it's got to get across to the audience as quickly and as effectively as possible.
Logo critic, Michael Evamy.
Thank you so much.
Thank you.
